awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science.  The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Thiago Ghirello Aur Lima is "The genetics of reproductive isolation in a copepod species lacking chromosomes that specify male or female." The host institution for this fellowship is Scripps Institution of Oceanography-UCSD, and the sponsoring scientist is Ronald Burton.
 
Studying the process by which new species are formed (speciation) explains how biological diversity has developed in nature. Studies of the genetic basis of speciation have focused on a few model systems, most which have chromosomes that specify male versus female (such as mammals and fruit flies). These studies have found that these chromosomes play an important role in the process of speciation, however, a large number of species in nature do not have such chromosomes, among them are many plants and reptiles, some fishes, crustaceans, insects and nematodes. By comparison, studying the process of speciation in species that lack chromosomes that specify male versus female may reveal novel biological patterns, previously unobserved in these model systems. The fellowship research uses the copepod Tigriopus californicus, a small crustacean that lacks male or female specifying chromosomes, to study the genetic basis of speciation. Different populations of this copepod are being hybridized in the laboratory, and the genome of the hybrids surveyed for regions that contribute to hybrid dysfunction. The premise is that these regions should harbor genes or genomic structures that contribute to speciation. The different hybrid crosses can be compared to determine if the same regions of the genome are contributing to hybrid dysfunction, and if certain chromosomes contribute disproportionately to this process in all crosses. The interactions within the hybrid's genome can also be assessed, in an effort to determine if certain parts of the genome play a special role in the process of speciation when a species does not have chromosomes that specify male versus female.  Results promise to provide general principles of evolutionary biology, as it will allow for comparative studies between species with different male versus female determination mechanisms.  

Training objectives include broadening knowledge in genetic techniques, specifically in functional genetics.  An educational component focuses on increasing the interest, knowledge and participation of underrepresented minorities in science by introducing K-12 students from underserved areas to current research at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO), by pairing SIO researchers with school teachers to create science lesson plans. These activities help students connect subjects they learn in the classroom with real world applications of these topics.

por.por_cntn:
Studying the process by which new species are formed (speciation), allows us to understand how biological diversity has developed in nature. Studies of the genetic basis of speciation have focused on a few model systems, most of which have sex chromosomes (such as mammals and fruit flies). These studies have found that sex chromosomes play an important role in the process of speciation. However, a large number of species in nature do not have sex chromosomes (such as many plants, reptiles, some fishes, crustaceans, insects and nematodes). It is therefore important to study the process of speciation in species that lack sex chromosomes as they may reveal novel biological patterns, previously unobserved in these model systems. This project used the copepod Tigriopus californicus, a small crustacean that lacks sex chromosomes, to study the genetic basis of speciation.

One interesting question to ask in this case is: in organisms that lack sex chromosomes, do other genetic factors become particularly important for the process of speciation? One good candidate for this would be the mitochondrial genome. The mitochondrion genome is small and only codes for a small number of the proteins it uses for all the important process it must perform. All other proteins used by the mitochondrion comes from the nuclear genome, and proteins from both of these genomes must work well together, and adapt together to local conditions. This means that populations that have been isolated for long periods of time, may have co-adapted mitochondrial-nuclear (mito-nuclear) factors that might not work well when combined in a hybrid genome, where different mito-nuclear factors are mixed in one genome.

In this project, I used crosses between populations of T. californicus to test if mito-nuclear problems are particularly important as a cause of hybrid inviability and sterility. By comparing three different crosses, I determined that mito-nuclear problems are more important than problems between nuclear-nuclear factors in causing hybrid inviability. But the relative importance of mito-nuclear versus nuclear-nuclear problems is dependent on which populations are being crossed. For hybrid sterility, I focused on males from one cross (between the Abalone Cove (AB) and San Diego (SD) populations). In this case, one chromosome (c2) appears to harbor factors that make nearly all males sterile if they have both copies of the chromosome coming from the AB population. In this specific case, it does not matter if the mitochondria are from SD or AB. Factors in other chromosomes in these hybrids also contribute to male hybrid sterility to a lower extent. In these cases, they are dependent on which mitochondria are present in the hybrids. Overall, these two studies suggest mito-nuclear incompatibilities may be particularly important in causing hybrid problems, but strong nuclear-nuclear problems may also lead to hybrid problems in some cases.

The second aim of this project was to identify the location of a hybrid incompatibility within a specific chromosome. We focused on the strongest incompatibility we have identified to date, in the cross between AB and SD. This incompatibility, located in chromosome 3, leads to hybrid inviability in second generation hybrids (F2), where 90% of individuals that are homozygous for SD in this region die within the first few days after hatching. We were able to pinpoint the location of this incompatibility to within ~2Mbp, and to determine that this is a maternal effect incompatibility, where an AB factor from the F1 mother causes lethality in F2 offspring that lack a rescue factor. The rescue factor would be present in the AB population but not in the SD population, causing F2 hybrids that are homozygous SD at this part of the chromosome to die soon after hatching. This type of hybrid incompatibility has only been observed in two other organisms at this point (C. elegans and T. castaneum).

The results of this research contributed interesting novel knowledge for the advancement of the field of evolutionary biology, and emphasized the need for comparative studies between species with different sex determination mechanisms. This fellowship also allowed me to work with Ocean Discovery Institute, a non-profit organization that helps bring science to schools in underserved areas of San Diego. During this fellowship, I worked with 5th graders on lab activities that introduce them to basic molecular biology skills (using T. californicus DNA for the activities); with 7th graders on how abiotic factors can affect organisms living in the intertidal zone; and accompanied two 2nd grade classes to a field trip to tidepools, where T. californicus lives, where they learned about adaptations to life in tidepools. In the summer of 2016 I spent a week in Bahia de Los Angeles, Mexico, with high school students from San Diego, helping them with the molecular biology portion of a project looking at the photobiology of the sea slug Elysia diomedea.
